snippet: A new study finds that young male fruit flies that have been rejected by females apparently self-medicate just like humans do.
abstract: Scientists report that young male fruit flies that have been rejected by females apparently self-medicate just like humans do, drowning their sorrows or frustrations for some of the same reasons; male flies subjected to what amounted to a long tease preferred food spiked with alcohol far more than male flies that were able to mate; study suggests that some elements of the brain’s reward system have changed very little during evolution.
lead_paragraph: A new study finds that young male fruit flies that have been rejected by females apparently self-medicate just like humans do.

headline.seo: Male Fruit Flies, Spurned by Females, Turn to Alcohol
headline.main: Learning From the Spurned and Tipsy Fruit Fly
